bioghist.p: Albert Croll Baugh (1891-1981) was a scholar of English language and literature and medieval studies. He was educated at the University of Pennsylvania. He served on the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania, where he taught Middle English literature and Chaucer, and in 1946 was appointed to the Felix Schelling Memorial Professorship, a post he held until his retirement in 1961. He served as the chair of the English Department from 1944 to 1957. He was the author of A History of the English Language, the editor of A Literary History of England, and the compiler of Chaucer, among other publications. He was also an active member of the Modern Language Association, serving on its editorial board (1930-1941 and 1946-1951), its executive committee (1943-1946), and as its president (1952).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Albert Croll Baugh. Materials include manuscript and typescript scholarly notes; manuscripts, typescripts, and proofs of Baugh's writings; reprints and offprints; a collection catalog of Baugh's books and serials; a small amount of correspondence with colleagues regarding scholarly articles, editing, and research; one letter from his son, a professor at Princeton; notes for an English I course (presumably taught by Baugh); and microfilms, photographs, and photostats of texts. The collection also includes a bound transcript of Ancrene Riwle that was given to Hope Emily Allen.
